title: What is the benefit of getting an Ivy League MBA? - Quora

response.answer_text: For me, the benefit was figuring out what I didn’t know. And it turns out that was a lot. Aside from the actual knowledge you will learn, you’re forced to sit in an environment with other intellectually acute people and learn from them. When else in your life are you given such an opportunity to stop and reflect on your life and your goals, through the lenses of various business subjects and peers? Then, of course, there’s the network, and when you’re walking around campus there’s no mistaking that you’re in the Ivy League. Its one thing to get educated; it’s another to be supported by the pride and camaraderie everyone feels by having “made it” to one of the most acclaimed institutions in modern society. That makes for a very helpful group of alums who are ready and willing to give you a hand up. Many here on Quora talk about the “benefits” of an MBA and of an Ivy League MBA specifically, and many go on about this or that feature. But, many miss what I consider to be the most prescient point: Are you an Ivy League MBA? In other words, is it in your identity? If it is, no amount of tuition or ROI calculations will deter you from applying and going for it. And, if you think you could get all that knowledge and networking from somewhere else, that’s probably a sign that earning an Ivy League MBA isn’t all that important to your identity. Because if it’s not important to your identity, there are a lot of other ways to spend a small mortgage and hundreds of hours of your life.

The same as the benefit of getting a Pac 10 PhD, or an SEC certificate in underwater basket weaving. Namely, none at all. Why? Because none of these things exist. The Ivy League is a Division I NCAA athletic conference. It does not confer degrees. And an MBA is a graduate degree. Graduate students do not in general compete in NCAA sports. The best business schools in the world are, in any case, not all ( or even mostly ) affiliated with colleges whose undergraduates compete in the Ivy League. But to answer the question I'm sure you meant to ask, a business degree from a top school should prepare you for a management role in a major corporation or other institution.
